title: 104_hr4162
content: The Act titled "Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996" allows certain individuals to continue participating in defined benefit plans under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. Sec. 211 of the Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to elect continued participation in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event, ensuring the accrual of benefits without a break in service. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue participating in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event, ensuring the accrual of benefits without a break in service. The period of continued participation is considered service with the employer for determining nonforfeitability and benefit accrual. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue participating in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. Earnings and forfeitures are not included in determining liability and obligations of the plan. Liability allocation in a multiemployer plan is determined by the plan sponsor or the last employer before the qualifying event. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows beneficiaries to continue in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. Participation period ends at normal retirement age, employer ceases plan, or benefits stop accruing. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. Beneficiaries must make timely contributions to fund any obligations of the plan for providing benefits. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to continue in a defined benefit plan after a qualifying event. The plan must allocate employer and employee contributions to beneficiaries in the same manner, with benefit accruals from voluntary employee contributions only available if they were prior to the qualifying event. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to receive compensation during continued participation, limited to 102 percent of the applicable contribution for the period. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to make monthly installment payments, with a 45-day grace period before the first contribution is due. The election period for continued participation must begin before benefits accrual would cease and last for at least 90 days. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to elect continued participation for at least 90 days. Any election made by one qualified beneficiary will also apply to other beneficiaries affected by the qualifying event. There is an exception for defined benefit plans with fewer than 20 employees. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to elect continued participation for at least 90 days. The applicable contribution is determined based on the actuarial value of benefit accruals. A qualified beneficiary includes any beneficiary under the plan before the qualifying event. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to elect continued participation for at least 90 days following a qualifying event within seven years of normal retirement age. Qualifying events include termination or reduction of employment hours, or the death of the participant. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 allows qualified beneficiaries to elect continued participation for at least 90 days following a qualifying event within seven years of normal retirement age. Qualifying events include termination or reduction of employment hours, or the death of the participant. SEC. 3. EFFECTIVE DATES. The Continued Participation Pension Act of 1996 applies to plan years starting on or after July 1, 1996. For defined benefit plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the Act's enactment, the Act does not apply until the last agreement terminates or January 1, 2000.
